results.justification: The document explicitly states the research aims to re-examine theoretical models of affect dynamics using data from a classroom study. It details the use of epistemic network analysis (ENA) and BROMP-based detectors.
Sections 3.1-3.3 provide a detailed description of the study context, learners, automated detectors, and ordered network analysis, outlining the steps taken in the study design.
The document does not mention the public availability of the raw or processed datasets.
There is no justification provided for why the data cannot be shared.
There is no mention of a data dictionary or codebook explaining variables, formats, or preprocessing steps.
Data collection methods are described, including pre- and post-surveys, and the use of BROMP observations during gameplay (Section 3.1 & 3.2).
The document does not mention the sharing of analysis code in an open repository.
There is no justification provided for why the code cannot be shared.
The document does not mention the sharing of code for data preparation.
Statistical methods like Ordered Network Analysis (ONA) are described, and the use of normalization techniques is mentioned (Section 3.3).
While statistical methods are mentioned, effect sizes, confidence intervals, and p-values are not explicitly reported in the provided text.
The document provides subjective context and interpretation of the results, particularly in the discussion of pleasurable frustration and the limitations of the BROMP detectors.
Data coding and analysis are not described in detail, and no coding scheme is shared.
Results are presented in tables (Table 2 & 3) and described in the text, detailing changes in affective states over time and differences based on self-efficacy.

The document discusses limitations, such as the inability of BROMP detectors to differentiate between types of frustration and the need for further investigation into the temporal scale of affective experiences (Section 5.3).
The document does not contain a link to a preregistration on platforms like the Open Science Foundation.
